title: Mental Health and PBC

content: If you have primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), you may find that you often have feelings of depression, anxiety, or fatigue. These feelings are all too common for people with this chronic liver disease. Understanding the condition’s physical effects can help you get a handle on managing its impact on your mental health.

content_blocks.text: If you have primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), you may find that you often have feelings of depression, anxiety, or fatigue. These feelings are all too common for people with this chronic liver disease. Understanding the condition’s physical effects can help you get a handle on managing its impact on your mental health.

sections.heading: Why PBC Can Cause Mental Health Concerns
content: There are several reasons why PBC can make you feel tired or down: Toxins. Toxins that get trapped in inflamed bile ducts can travel from your liver to your brain. This causes a condition called hepatic encephalopathy (HE). HE results in imbalances in your neurotransmitters, the chemicals that send signals throughout your brain and body. You might notice trouble concentrating, feel confused, or become forgetful. Severe itching . Pruritus, or itching, is a common symptom of PBC. It can cause emotional distress, stop you from thinking clearly, and keep you from getting a good night’s sleep. Stress due to a chronic illness . You may worry about your how PBC is affecting your physical health. Prolonged stress can affect your physical well-being and turn into a negative cycle of cause and effect.

You may worry about your how PBC is affecting your physical health. Prolonged stress can affect your physical well-being and turn into a negative cycle of cause and effect.

sections.heading: Daytime fatigue
content: Common symptoms of PBC connected to your mental and emotional well-being include: . Fatigue is one of the most common effects of PBC. Even if you feel you slept well, you may be so tired during the day that daily tasks and social activities become difficult. This can leave you feeling isolated and down. Sleep disturbances . You may have trouble sleeping well if you have PBC. Experts aren’t sure why it leads to sleep disturbances. But one study found that up to 85% of the people with PBC slept poorly or felt tired upon waking up. Depression and anxiety . Chronic health conditions like PBC that tend to get worse over time can add to feelings of loss of purpose, emotional distress, or a general sense of a lower quality of life.

sections.heading: Treatments for Mental Health Symptoms of PBC
content: There is help available for the mental health symptoms of PBC, and there are also steps you can take yourself. Talk to your doctor about what you’re feeling. They can suggest ways to treat your concerns or refer you to other sources of support. Also let your doctor know about any new exercise routines or supplements you’re thinking about trying. They can let you know if anything may not be right for you or your current treatment plan.

sections.heading: Treatments for Mental Health Symptoms of PBC
content: There is help available for the mental health symptoms of PBC, and there are also steps you can take yourself. Talk to your doctor about what you’re feeling. They can suggest ways to treat your concerns or refer you to other sources of support. Also let your doctor know about any new exercise routines or supplements you’re thinking about trying. They can let you know if anything may not be right for you or your current treatment plan.

content_blocks.text: There is help available for the mental health symptoms of PBC, and there are also steps you can take yourself. Talk to your doctor about what you’re feeling. They can suggest ways to treat your concerns or refer you to other sources of support. Also let your doctor know about any new exercise routines or supplements you’re thinking about trying. They can let you know if anything may not be right for you or your current treatment plan.

sections.heading: Medications
content: Treatment options include: SSRI antidepressants. These medications can help improve your mood and lessen depression. SSRI stands for “selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.” These medications increase the amount of the hormone serotonin, which helps regulate emotion. SSRIs can work well, but PBC can make your body process them differently. They may carry a risk of liver damage, so it’s important that you take them as prescribed and go to all follow-up appointments. Some SSRIs are safer for the liver than others, including: Citalopram (Celexa) Escitalopram (Lexapro) Fluoxetine (prozac) Paroxetine (Paxil) Sertraline (Zoloft) Mirtazipine (Remeron). This is another type of antidepressant called a tetracyclic. It has been shown to have a lower rate of liver damage than some other antidepressants and may also help you sleep better. Other drugs ease physical symptoms of PBC that may affect your quality of life and how you feel emotionally. Cholestyramine , which can remove bile from your blood, is a medication commonly used for itching due to PBC. Studies show that around 5% to 10% of people with ongoing itching from biliary disease have trouble getting enough sleep, depression, and thoughts of suicide.

sections.heading: Other treatment options
content: Counseling or psychotherapy . Therapy can help you deal with the concerns you have about PBC and how it affects your life. Talk to your doctor about finding a qualified therapist or counselor who understands the challenges of the disease. SAMe. An early study of this over-the-counter supplement showed that some people who took it felt less fatigue and itching. Talk to your doctor before starting any supplement, as they can interact with medications. Bright light therapy. This is also known as phototherapy. It can help reset sleep patterns in some people who have trouble falling asleep. A light source, such as a lamp timer, gradually turns on earlier and earlier in the morning to wake you up, and stays on for an hour or more. The new pattern may help you fall asleep more easily at night so that you feel more rested.

sections.heading: Self-Care for Mental Health Symptoms of PBC
content: There are things you can do to help manage the emotional effects of PBC and the fatigue that can make them worse. Here are some self-care options you can try:

content_blocks.text: There are things you can do to help manage the emotional effects of PBC and the fatigue that can make them worse. Here are some self-care options you can try:

sections.heading: Tips for better sleep
content: Keep your bedroom dark, quiet, and cool. Limit daytime naps. Stick to a regular nighttime schedule. Find a relaxing routine before bedtime, such as listening to calm music, gentle stretching, or reading. Avoid using electronic devices near bedtime. Don’t fret if you don’t fall asleep. Worrying about not sleeping will just keep you up longer. Tips to manage stress Relaxation techniques like meditation, yoga, or deep breathing can help you feel calm and better able to take things in stride. Stretching and focusing on relaxing your muscles can relax your mind as well as your body. Get outside, even for a stroll. It can change your mindset. Eat a healthy, balanced diet. Studies have noted that poor nutrition can be linked to depression, so eating a diet high in nutrients and low in sugar, salt, and fat is good for your mental as well as physical health. Some people find journaling to express their thoughts and feelings helpful.

Some people find journaling to express their thoughts and feelings helpful.

sections.heading: Spend time with family and friends
content: . Reaching out to friends and relatives can be a great mood-changer. Even something simple like going to a movie, taking a walk, or having a meal out with others can lift your spirits. Develop new interests. Take up a hobby or learn something new to help you switch your focus from things that bother you. Gardening, carpentry, music, and learning about a new subject are just a few of the ideas that could help you reset.

Gardening, carpentry, music, and learning about a new subject are just a few of the ideas that could help you reset.

sections.heading: Getting Support Through Community
content: Whatever you’re feeling, someone else with PBC has been there too. Joining a support group is a good way to meet others who know what you’re going through. Members can share self-care tips, pass along information on other resources, and offer moral support that can mean so much. You can find information on both in-person and online support groups and other emotional health resources through several organizations, including the American Liver Foundation , the Community Liver Alliance , and the PBCers Organization .

meta_description: PBC affects both your physical and mental health. Learn why, as well as tips for emotional health self-care and how to get the support you need.
